Title: ‘Mapping our conservation future’ scoping workshop
Meetings summary: The ‘Mapping our conservation future’ scoping workshop on 6th June 2017 was convened by UNEP-WCMC and focused on scaling up ambition for area-based conservation. It brought together an international collection of biodiversity-related institutions to discuss three key questions: 1. How can we provide meaningful data on biodiversity at a scale needed for decision making? 2. What is needed for the biodiversity community to speak with one voice on biodiversity prioritization - i.e. where is important to focus conservation efforts? 3. How can we assess where important biodiversity is, and is not, being effectively managed?
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: This workshop focused on the current state of Aichi Target 11 and how this could be followed up post-2020.
Link to further information: A workshop report is available on request: post-2020@unep-wcmc.org

Title: IUCN WCPA Beyond the Aichi Targets Task Force
Meetings summary: The meeting focused on developing an engagement strategy on how to best work with people all over the world to gather input and build support to scale up conservation areas using protected areas as a key conservation tool. This strategy would be informed by the best available science in which the Task Force will seek to understand perspectives on what are truly sustainable area-based conservation targets.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: The purpose of IUCN's Beyond the Aichi Task Force is two-fold. It aims to help build global momentum for the Promise of Sydney to scale up conservation, using protected areas as the key conservation tool. Furthermore, it aims to ensure that, in 2020, new global conservation targets for spatial conservation are set that would be meaningful for achieving the CBD's basic purpose, which is the conservation of biological diversity and the halting of biodiversity loss.

Title: Fourth International Marine Protected Areas Congress (IMPAC 4)
Meetings summary: The IMPAC series are a high-quality and professionally coordinated international congress which allows the exchange of ideas, defines recommendations on policy processes, assists in the establishment and ongoing implementation of global, lasting, ecologically representative and effectively managed network of MPAs and engages stakeholders. Chile hosted the Fourth International Marine Protected Areas Congress, IMPAC4, with the motto 'Marine Protected Areas: Bringing the people and ocean together'. The focus was on the need to highlight the intricate nature of ocean-human relationship and the benefits of marine protected areas (MPA) and the ocean for millions that depends on their ecosystem services.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: IMPAC4 was one of the last milestones in the road of conferences on marine conservation before reaching the 2020 deadline for the Aichi Targets. It was a major opportunity to evaluate and review practices in MPAs towards fulfilling Target 11, and for combining MPA management with advances on UN Sustainable Development Goal 14, Oceans, Seas and Marine Resources. It was also a great opportunity to call attention to the important role of the oceans in the control of the planet´s climate, urging to protect this crucial ecosystem service.

Title: Half-Earth Day
Organisers: E. O. Wilson Biodiversity Foundation, National Geographic
Meetings summary: Scientists and conservationists from around the world were joined by special guests, including eminent biologist Edward O. Wilson and legendary recording artist Paul Simon, to celebrate the planet’s first-ever Half-Earth Day on Oct. 23. The all-day inaugural event, co-convened by the E.O. Wilson Biodiversity Foundation and National Geographic, highlighted efforts to halt rising extinction rates and help conserve half the planet. Half-Earth Day featured two large-scale public events, and a morning scientific session, that brought together scientists to discuss their research regarding how we can achieve the Half-Earth goal.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: Half-Earth' is an inspiring goal that would drive conservation efforts to a new level. In the run-up to 2020, advocates of this idea are aiming to provide scientific leadership on how best to manage 50 percent of the planet to protect life on Earth.

Title: GEO-XIV Plenary
Meetings summary: Group on Earth Observation (GEO) is a global network of national governments and partner organisations that works in the areas of sustainable development and sound environmental management. Over 700 people from diverse geographies, sectors and technical areas came together for GEO week from 23-27 October 2017 in Washington, DC, to explore the use and applications of Earth observations for the benefit of humankind. The sessions of GEO-XIV included 'Earth Observations in Public Policy', 'Earth Observations in the Commercial Sector', 'Earth Observations in International Development', '2017-2019 GEO Work Programme' and 'National Earth Observations'.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: The GEO Plenary is the highest decision-making body of GEO, a partnership that envisions a future where decisions and actions for the benefit of humankind are informed by coordinated, comprehensive and sustained Earth observations. GEO helps identify gaps and reduce duplication in the areas of sustainable development and sound environmental management.

Title: 1st Bogis-Bossey Dialogue for Transformational Change on Biodiversity
Meetings summary: With the goal of identifying a transformative agenda for action that will engage multi-level systemic change in sectors and domains that have an impact on or benefit from biodiversity, and with a view to contribute to discussions on an ambitious, innovative, yet pragmatic post-2020 global biodiversity framework, the Secretariat of the Convention convened the first of a series of dialogues from 12 to 14 November 2017, in Bogis-Bossey, Switzerland, with the support of the Government of Switzerland. This meeting convened close to 50 experts in transitions, communication and finance, among others, as part of the "Friends of the CBD" meeting series.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: A large focus of the meeting involved identifying barriers to, and opportunities for, transformational change to address the drivers of biodiversity loss. Discussions led to a constructive exchange of views and a number of commitments relating to how the CBD and wider biodiversity community can leverage transformational change, both in the lead up to 2020 and through the post-2020 global biodiversity framework.

Title: 69th Meeting of the CITES Standing Committee
Meetings summary: Meeting of national CITES Authorities (primarily Management Authorities) to discuss a variety of issues related to the implementation of the Convention. Including National Ivory Action Plans, illegal trade, trade in timber species, electronic permitting, etc.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: Key meeting on wildlife trade and sustainable use ahead of CITES CoP18 in 2019. There is cooperation, coordination and synergies amongst the biodiversity-related conventions.

Title: Third Meeting of the UN Environment Assembly (UNEA 3)
Meetings summary: The third meeting of the UN Environment Assembly (UNEA 3), will be held, on an exceptional basis, from 4-6 December 2017, with the high-level segment taking place on 5-6 December, and the Open Ended Committee of Permanent Representatives from 29 November to 1 December. The event considered the overarching theme of pollution. Outcomes included: a political declaration on pollution, linked to the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), resolutions and decisions adopted by Member States to address specific dimensions of pollution, voluntary commitments by governments, private sector entities and civil society organizations to clean up the planet, and the Clean Planet Pledge, a collection of individual commitments to take personal action to end pollution in all its forms. UNEA-3 was preceded by: the Global Major Groups and Stakeholders Forum (27-28 November), the Committee of Permanent Representatives (29 November – 1 December), the Science Policy Forum (2-3 December), and the Sustainable Innovation Expo (4-6 December 2017).
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: Progress in development of the sixth edition of the Global Environment Outlook was be made available to governments. While Regional environmental assessments for the sixth Global Environment Outlook were published in 2016, the broader Global Environment Outlook will be available in full to decision makers and the public in 2019.

Title: WWF Towards a new CBD Strategy 2021-2030 First International Workshop
Meetings summary: The first expert workshop will convene in Montreal prior to SBSTTA-21 to discuss the vision, mission and five strategic goals of the current Strategic Plan 2011-2020. The following questions will be addressed: 1. Should the vision, mission, and five strategic goals be maintained, adjusted, or amended? 2. Do we need additional goals until 2030 to better link with the SDGs?
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: Intermediate results will be presented at the margins of SBSTTA-21, SBSTTA-22 and SBI-2. The discussion paper will be presented at the 14th Conference of the Parties 2018 in Egypt.

Title: Twenty-First Meeting of the Subsidiary Body on Scientific, Technical and Technological Advice of the CBD (SBSTTA-21)
Meetings summary: The agenda included 'scenarios for the 2050 Vision for biodiversity, and links between the Aichi Biodiversity Targets and the Sustainable Development Goals', 'sustainable wildlife management', 'biodiversity and human health', 'mainstreaming of biodiversity into the sectors of energy and mining, infrastructure, manufacturing and processing industry, and health', and the 'fifth edition of the Global Biodiversity Outlook'.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: The meeting started to discuss the 2050 vision which will set the context for the revised Strategic Plan for Biodiversity that would be adopted during the 15th Conference of the Parties in Beijing.

Title: International Water Summit 2018
Meetings summary: The International Water Summit (IWS) is a global platform dedicated to developing solutions for water sustainability in arid regions. IWS brings together 9,2000 visitors from 111 countries, including government leaders, policy makers, entrepreneurs and academics, to accelerate the development of new sustainable strategies and technologies. This event takes place as part of Abu Dhabi Sustainability Week.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: This represents an opportunity to receive information from sectors on how the framework could facilitate the mainstreaming of biodiversity.

Title: Expert Workshop on Protected Areas and Other Effective Area-based Conservation Measures for Achieving Aichi Biodiversity Target 11
Meetings summary: This workshop is organised to provide scientific and technical advice on definition, management approaches, and identification of other effective area-based conservation measures, as well as their role in achieving Aichi Biodiversity Target 11. The technical expert workshop on protected areas and other effective area-based conservation measures and their role in achieving Aichi Biodiversity Target 11 (2017-099), will be held in conjunction with the expert workshop on marine protected areas and other effective area-based conservation measures for achieving Aichi Biodiversity Target 11 in marine and coastal areas (2017-098), with joint sessions on relevant topics.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: Future targets will consider other effective area-based conservation measures (OECMs) in terrestrial and marine realms. This meeting is for National Governments to agree on the framework that has been developed.
Link to further information: Link for terrestrial meeting documents: https://www.cbd.int/meetings/PAEM-2018-01. Link for marine meeting documents: https://www.cbd.int/meetings/005753.

Title: Ninth Session of the World Urban Forum (WUF9)
Meetings summary: The Ninth Session of the World Urban Forum will be the first session to focus on the implementation of the New Urban Agenda adopted in Habitat III. In the New Urban Agenda, participating States request the report of the implementation of the Agenda to incorporate, to the extent possible, the inputs of multilateral organizations, civil society, the private sector and academia and to build on existing platforms such as the World Urban Forum. WUF9 will be an instrumental to substantively feed into the inputs for the first report of the implementation of the New Urban Agenda. The Forum will also contribute to global mobilization towards advocating for the common vision on sustainable urban development in advancing on the achievement of the Agenda 2030 and the Sustainable Development Goals.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: This represents an opportunity to receive information from sectors on how the framework could facilitate the mainstreaming of biodiversity.

Title: Deadline for comments on the draft document: 'proposals for a comprehensive and participatory process for the preparation of the post-2020 biodiversity framework'
Meetings summary: The thirteenth meeting of the Conference of the Parties requested the Executive Secretary to prepare, in consultation with the Bureau and for consideration by the Subsidiary Body on Implementation at its second meeting, a proposal for a comprehensive and participatory preparatory process and timetable for the follow-up to the Strategic Plan for Biodiversity 2011-2020 (decision XIII/1, para. 34). In response to this decision, a draft document on proposals for a comprehensive and participatory process for the preparation of the post-2020 biodiversity framework had been made available for peer review. The deadline for comments, as well as any other relevant input, should be sent by e-mail to secretariat@cbd.int no later than 16 February 2018.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: The present note has been prepared by the Executive Secretary to provide the Subsidiary Body on Implementation with proposals concerning the process for the development of a follow up to the Strategic Plan for Biodiversity 2011-2020. It draws on the submissions received in response to a notification issued inviting Parties, other Governments, relevant organizations and indigenous peoples and local communities to provide comments and inputs on the process for developing the post 2020 global biodiversity framework. It also draws on experiences in developing the Strategic Plan for Biodiversity 2011-2020 in the lead-up to the tenth meeting of the Conference of the Parties.

Title: ZSL’s Symposium: ‘Safeguarding space for nature, securing our future: developing a post-2020 strategy’
Meetings summary: This symposium will bring together international scientists, conservation practitioners, policy-makers, business leaders, civil society and donors to (1) review the science informing future area-based conservation targets, (2) evaluate the implications of various policy options, (3) provide balanced, evidence-based recommendations to Parties to the CBD and other policy processes and (4) raise awareness of the need for a more ambitious, holistic and effective strategy on space for nature, incorporating protected areas and other effective area-based conservation measures.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: The outputs of the meeting will feed into post-2020 negotiations in the run up to the CBD’s 14th Conference of the Parties and the High-Level Political Forum on Sustainable Development of the UN’s Economic and Social Council later in 2018. This will help to ensure that nature conservation is at the heart of sustainable development.

Title: UN World Wildlife Day 2018
Meetings summary: On 20 December 2013, at its 68th session, the UN General Assembly (UNGA) proclaimed 3 March - the day of signature of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) - as UN World Wildlife Day. This day was proclaimed to celebrate and raise awareness of the world's wild animals and plants. The theme for World Wildlife Day 2018 is 'Big Cats'. Using the expanded definition of big cats, the Day will raise awareness on the conservation of the lion, tiger, leopard and jaguar, as well as the cheetah, snow leopard, puma, clouded leopard and related species.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: Wildlife conservation is at the heart of the Strategic Plan for Biodiversity, which includes in its mission to, “take effective and urgent action to halt the loss of biodiversity”. Aichi Biodiversity Target 12, for example, aims to prevent the extinction of threatened species by 2020 and improve the conservation status of those species most in decline. World Wildlife Day heightens awareness and brings to attention the importance of doing our utmost to preserving biodiversity.

Title: World Ocean Summit 2018
Meetings summary: Since 2012, The Economist Group has hosted the World Ocean Summit, leveraging their convening power and reputation for quality, objective journalism to bridge the sometimes dissonant perspectives of business, government and civil society in how the troubled seas are used. The vision is an ocean in robust health and with a vital economy. The purpose is to accelerate the transition to the sustainable use of the ocean.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: This represents an opportunity to receive information from sectors on how the framework could facilitate the mainstreaming of biodiversity.

Title: Plenary of the Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services Sixth session (IPBES 6)
Meetings summary: The Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (IPBES) is the intergovernmental body which assesses the state of biodiversity and of the ecosystem services it provides to society, in response to requests from decision makers. The plenary of the IPBES reviews progress on its work programme. Reports will be considered for adoption and their respective summary for policymakers will be considered for approval.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: IPBES assessments are already providing the basis for informed policy-making at the international level, as well as at the national level. The regional and subregional assessments for Africa, Americas, Asia-Pacific and Europe and Central Asia together with the Thematic assessment of land degradation and restoration will be considered by the Plenary.

Title: 8th World Water Forum
Meetings summary: The World Water Forum is the world's biggest water-related, bringing together all those interested in the theme of water. Its mission is “to promote awareness, build political commitment and trigger action on critical water issues at all levels, to facilitate the efficient conservation, protection, development, planning, management and use of water in all its dimensions on an environmentally sustainable basis for the benefit of all life”.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: This represents an opportunity to receive information from sectors on how the framework could facilitate the mainstreaming of biodiversity.

Title: 2nd Bogis-Bossey Dialogue for Transformational Change on Biodiversity
Meetings summary: This is the second in the a series of dialogues, convened by the Secretariat of the Convention, in Bogis-Bossey, Switzerland, with the support of the Government of Switzerland. The second dialogue is planned for early 2018 to bring Parties together to discuss the outcomes of the first dialogue and further work to identify a transformative agenda for action, with a view to contributing to discussions on an ambitious yet pragmatic and innovative post-2020 global biodiversity framework.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: The goal of the series is to identify a transformative agenda for action that will engage multi-level systemic change in sectors and domains that have an impact on or benefit from biodiversity, with a view to contribute to discussions on an ambitious, innovative, yet pragmatic post-2020 global biodiversity framework.

Title: CCI Expert Workshop: Framing the Future for Biodiversity
Organisers: UNEP-WCMC, BirdLife International, RSPB, Cambridge University, IUCN, ZSL, Defra
Meetings summary: In setting goals and targets, and working to achieve them, the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) uses various forms of knowledge in diverse ways, working with a range of organisations. However, there is no overall plan, and to date there has been no real attempt to develop a coherent picture of what knowledge base is needed, where that knowledge is to come from and how. To help address this gap the Cambridge Conservation Initiative (CCI) is planning to convene an expert meeting in April 2018 that will bring together key players involved in different aspects of developing and implementing plans and strategies for the conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity, and reviewing their implementation.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: Outputs from the meeting will be introduced to governments and other stakeholders at CBD-related meetings in 2018, as governments debate and decide on the process for negotiating a post-2020 global biodiversity framework. It is intended that the report and associated communication will lead to improved recognition of the importance of evidence and the processes for delivering it in appropriate ways.

Title: CCI Communications Workshop: Framing the Future for Biodiversity
Organisers: UNEP-WCMC, BirdLife International, RSPB, Cambridge University, IUCN, ZSL, Defra
Meetings summary: The Cambridge Conservation Initiative will host a one-day meeting at the David Attenborough Building, Cambridge, UK, on 13th April 2018, focused on biodiversity communications. The day will centre on exchanging and coordinating information on existing ongoing communications activities and will explore the most effective mechanisms to ensure coherent communication messages and activities in the lead up to 2020. It will discuss the barriers to transformational change in the biodiversity agenda and how biodiversity messaging can be made most effective for different audiences.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: For ambitious and robust commitments on a post-2020 global biodiversity framework to be successful there needs to be a major, coordinated and impactful communications movement that resonates across sectors.

Title: 17th Session of the United Nations Permanent Forum on Indigenous Issues (UNPFII)
Organisers: UN Division for Social Policy and Development Indigenous Peoples
Meetings summary: This years theme will be “Indigenous peoples’ collective rights to lands, territories and resources”.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: It is expected that recommendations will be made to the CBD, based on outcomes from discussions during the Forum.

Title: World Conference on Marine Biodiversity 2018
Meetings summary: The World Conference on Marine Biodiversity (WCMB) has become the major focal assembly to share research outcomes, management and policy issues, and discussions on the role of biodiversity in sustaining ocean ecosystems. Arranged on a 3 - 4 year cycle, prior WCMB meetings have each attracted leading specialists from around the world, and catalysed numerous sidebar sessions on marine biodiversity issues. The 4th World Conference on Marine Biodiversity will bring together scientists, practitioners, and policy makers to discuss and advance our understanding of the importance and current state of biodiversity in the marine environment. Through a mix of keynote sessions, contributed talks and posters, and bookable venues for focused meetings, the conference program will address marine biodiversity across a deliberately wide range of relevant sectors. Participation will be encouraged from the broadest possible range of stakeholder groups from academics to industry.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: The 4th WCMB will ‘connect’ scientists with decision and policy makers, NGOs and industry. The conference will cover broad areas of current marine biodiversity research and policy challenges, as well as selected 'Aichi' goals.

Title: World Environment Day
Meetings summary: World Environment Day is the United Nations’ most important day for encouraging worldwide awareness and action for the protection of our environment. Since it began in 1974, it has grown to become a global platform for public outreach that is widely celebrated in over 100 countries.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: The celebration of this day provides an opportunity to broaden the basis for an enlightened opinion and responsible conduct by individuals, enterprises and communities in preserving and enhancing the environment. This will be a good opportunity for driving the momentum and public pressure for the upcoming CBD COP14.

Title: Fifth European Congress of Conservation Biology
Meetings summary: The theme of the Fifth European Congress of Conservation Biology (ECCB2018) is planetary wellbeing – a concept that captures the wellbeing of people as well as the integrity and sustainability of Earth's ecosystems. ECCB2018 provides a forum to discuss and develop solutions for some of the greatest challenges faced by humanity by bringing together natural and social scientists, practitioners, industry members and government decision-makers.

Title: 22nd Meeting of the Subsidiary Body on Scientific, Technical and Technological Advice (SBSTTA-22)
Meetings summary: Article 25 of the Convention on Biological Diversity establishes an open-ended intergovernmental scientific advisory body known as the Subsidiary Body on Scientific, Technical and Technological Advice (SBSTTA) to provide the Conference of the Parties (COP) and, as appropriate, its other subsidiary bodies, with timely advice relating to the implementation of the Convention.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: As a subsidiary body of the COP, SBSTTA is to report regularly to the COP on all aspects of its work. Multidisciplinary and open to participation by all Parties, SBSTTA comprises government representatives competent in the relevant field of expertise. Its functions include: providing assessments of the status of biological diversity, providing assessments of the types of measures taken in accordance with the provisions of the Convention, and responding to questions that the COP may put to the body.

Title: The 4th Blue Planet Symposium
Meetings summary: The 4th GEO Blue Planet Symposium will serve as a forum for discussion of ocean and coastal information needs for sustainable development, Blue Growth and societal awareness. The symposium will bring together producers of ocean and coastal information and current and potential users of ocean and coastal information, who will share their experience with the audience.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: GEO Blue Planet experts have a demonstrated capacity to bridge the gap between data and services, to deliver usable information that supports informed decision-making and address policy mandates toward reaching sustainable development.

Title: 2nd meeting of the Subsidiary Body on Implementation (SBI-2)
Meetings summary: The four functions and core areas of work of SBI consist of: (a) review of progress in implementation, (b) strategic actions to enhance implementation, (c) strengthening means of implementation, and (d) operations of the convention and the Protocols. The Bureau of the Conference of the Parties serves as the Bureau of the Subsidiary Body on Implementation.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: The proposed prepatory process for the development of post-2020 global biodiversity framework will be considered. The meeting will provide a recommendation to CBD COP-14 and requests the Executive Secretary to begin implementing relevant elements.

Title: Food and Agriculture Organisation Committee on Fisheries (COFI 33)
Meetings summary: The Committee on Fisheries (COFI), a subsidiary body of the FAO Council, was established by the FAO Conference at its Thirteenth Session in 1965. The Committee presently constitutes the only global inter-governmental forum where major international fisheries and aquaculture problems and issues are examined and recommendations addressed to governments, regional fishery bodies, NGOs, fishworkers, FAO and international community, periodically on a world-wide basis. The 33rd Session of the FAO Committee on Fisheries (COFI) is scheduled to be held in Rome from 9 to 13 July 2018.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: The provisional agenda covers biodiversity, including biodiversity mainstreaming in the work of FAO concerning fisheries and aquaculture.

Title: High-level Political Forum on Sustainable Development (HLPF) 2018
Meetings summary: The theme of HLPF 2018 will be: ‘Transformation towards sustainable and resilient societies’. The sub-set of Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) to be reviewed in depth by HLPF 2018 will be: SDG 6 (clean water and sanitation), SDG 7 (affordable and clean energy), SDG 11 (sustainable cities and communities), SDG 12 (responsible consumption and production), and SDG 15 (life on land). Goal 17 (Strengthen the means of implementation and revitalize the Global Partnership for Sustainable Development) is also considered each year. In addition, 48 countries are expected to present their Voluntary National Reviews (VNRs).
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: The HLPF is the main United Nations platform on sustainable development and it has a central role in the follow-up and review of the 2030 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) at the global level. As governments have made these commitments, relevant aspects of their agenda's and the follow-ups will be reflected in the post-2020 biodiversity strategy.

Title: Food and Agriculture Organisation Committee on Forests (COFO 24)
Meetings summary: The Committee on Forestry (COFO) is the highest FAO Forestry statutory body. The biennial sessions of COFO (held at FAO headquarters in Rome, Italy) bring together heads of forest services and other senior government officials to identify emerging policy and technical issues, to seek solutions and to advise FAO and others on appropriate action. Other international organizations and, increasingly, non-governmental groups participate in COFO. Participation in COFO is open to all FAO member countries.

Title: 73rd Session of the UN General Assembly (UNGA 73)
Meetings summary: The 73rd session of the UN General Assembly (UNGA 73) will open on 18 September 2018. The first day of the high-level General Debate will be Tuesday, 25 September 2018.

Title: 2018 G20 (thirteenth meeting) – Buenos Aires summit
Meetings summary: The Group of Twenty, or G20, is the central forum for international cooperation on financial and economic issues. The G20 countries account for more than four fifths of gross world product and three quarters of global trade, and are home to almost two thirds of the world’s population. Decisions taken by the G20 are influential and help to bring about reform at both the national and international level. Argentina took over the presidency of the G20 on 1 December 2017, with the forum’s main activities taking place over the course of 2018. The final event will be the Leaders' Summit on 30 November and 1 December.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: Egypt will be invited to the G20 Summit in 2018. With Mexico and China also in attendance, this will be a good influencing opportunity.

Title: 70th Meeting of the CITES Standing Committee
Meetings summary: Meeting of national CITES Authorities (primarily Management Authorities) to discuss a variety of issues related to the implementation of the Convention. Including interpretation and implementation issues, trade control and traceability and species-specific matters.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: Key meeting on wildlife trade and sustainable use ahead of CITES CoP18 in 2019. There is cooperation, coordination and synergies amongst the biodiversity-related conventions.

Title: Food and Agriculture Organisation Committee on Agriculture (COAG-26)
Meetings summary: The Committee on Agriculture (COAG) is one of FAO’s Governing Bodies providing overall policy and regulatory guidance on issues relating to agriculture, livestock, food safety, nutrition, rural development and natural resource management.

Title: Committee on World Food Security (CFS-46)
Meetings summary: The Committee on World Food Security (CFS) is the foremost inclusive international and intergovernmental platform for all stakeholders to work together to ensure food security and nutrition for all. The Committee reports to the UN General Assembly through the Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC) and to FAO Conference.

Title: 13th meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Ramsar Convention on Wetlands (Ramsar COP13)
Meetings summary: The 13th Meeting of the Conference of the Contracting Parties to the Ramsar Convention on Wetlands (COP13) will take place in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, from 21-29 October 2018. The Ramsar Convention on Wetlands is the intergovernmental treaty that provides the global framework for the conservation and wise use of wetlands. Every three years, representatives of the governments of each of the Contracting Parties meet as the Conference of the Contracting Parties (COP), to agree on a work programme and budgetary arrangements for the next triennium and consider guidance on a range of ongoing and emerging environmental issues.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: The Ramsar Convention on Wetlands is a “Rio Convention”. Its sister Rio Conventions are the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change, the Convention on Biological Diversity and the Convention to Combat Desertification. The three are intrinsically linked. It is in this context that the Joint Liaison Group was set up to boost cooperation among the Conventions, with the ultimate aim of developing synergies in their activities on issues of mutual concern. The Ramsar Convention's next triennium will run until 2021.

Title: 48th Meeting of the Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals (CMS) Standing Committee
Meetings summary: Meeting to discuss management and implementation issues regarding the conservation of migratory species.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: There is cooperation, coordination and synergies amongst the biodiversity-related conventions.

Title: GEO-XV Plenary
Meetings summary: Group on Earth Observation (GEO) is a global network of national governments and partner organisations that works in the areas of sustainable development and sound environmental management. Over 700 people from diverse geographies, sectors and technical areas came together for GEO week to explore the use and applications of Earth observations for the benefit of humankind. The GEO Plenary is the highest decision-making body of GEO.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: The partnership envisions a future where decisions and actions for the benefit of humankind are informed by coordinated, comprehensive and sustained Earth observations. GEO helps identify gaps and reduce duplication in the areas of sustainable development and sound environmental management.

Title: 14th meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD COP14)
Meetings summary: The Conference of the Parties is the governing body of the Convention, and advances implementation of the Convention through the decisions it takes at its periodic meetings. The Fourteenth meeting of the Conference of the Parties (COP 14) will be held in Egypt, from 10-22 November 2018.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: Penultimate meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the CBD, before the new biodiversity strategy is adopted. The proposed prepatory process will be considered for the development of the post-2020 global biodiversity framework.

Title: 9th Meeting of the Parties serving as the meeting of the Parties to the Cartagena Protocol on Biosafety (COPMOP9)
Meetings summary: The Cartagena Protocol on Biosafety to the Convention on Biological Diversity is an international agreement which aims to ensure the safe handling, transport and use of living modified organisms (LMOs) resulting from modern biotechnology that may have adverse effects on biological diversity, taking also into account risks to human health. The Conference of the Parties serving as the meeting of the Parties to the Protocol (COP-MOP) currently meets every two years in conjunction with the regular meetings of the Conference of the Parties (COP) to the Convention on Biological Diversity.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: The proposed preparatory process will be considered for the development of the post-2020 global biodiversity framework.

Title: Third meeting of the Conference of the Parties serving as the meeting of the Parties to the Nagoya Protocol on Access and Benefit-sharing (COPMOP3)
Meetings summary: The Nagoya Protocol on Access to Genetic Resources and the Fair and Equitable Sharing of Benefits Arising from their Utilization to the Convention on Biological Diversity is an international agreement which aims at sharing the benefits arising from the utilization of genetic resources in a fair and equitable way. The Conference of the Parties serving as the meeting of the Parties to the Protocol (COP-MOP) currently meets every two years in conjunction with the regular meetings of the Conference of the Parties (COP) to the Convention on Biological Diversity.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: The proposed preparatory process will be considered for the development of the post-2020 global biodiversity framework.

Title: Fourth Meeting of the UN Environment Assembly (UNEA 4)
Meetings summary: The UN Environment Assembly is the world's highest-level decision-making body on the environment. It has the universal membership of all 193 UN Member States and the full involvement of UN organizations, specialized agencies, inter-governmental organizations, civil society and the private sector. In bringing together these varied communities, the Assembly provides a ground-breaking platform for leadership on global environmental policy.

Title: 74th Session of the UN General Assembly (UNGA 74)
Meetings summary: The 74th session of the UN General Assembly (UNGA 74) will open on 17 September 2019. The first day of the high-level General Debate will be Monday, 30 September 2019. In accordance with paragraph 6 (b) of UN General Assembly resolution 67/290, the High-level Political Forum on Sustainable Development (HLPF) shall be convened by the President of the General Assembly for a period of two days at the beginning of the session of the Assembly. In paragraph 87 of its resolution 70/1, the Assembly decided that the next HLPF under the auspices of the UNGA would be held in 2019. In paragraph 132 of the annex to resolution 69/313, Heads of State and Government decided that the High-level Dialogue on Financing for Development of the Assembly would be held back -to back with the HLPF under the auspices of the Assembly when the HLPF is convened every four years.

Title: Twenty-fourth Conference of the Parties to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC COP24)
Meetings summary: Preventing “dangerous” human interference with the climate system is the ultimate aim of the UNFCCC.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: The UNFCCC is a “Rio Convention”, one of three adopted at the “Rio Earth Summit” in 1992. Its sister Rio Conventions are the UN Convention on Biological Diversity and the Convention to Combat Desertification. The three are intrinsically linked. It is in this context that the Joint Liaison Group was set up to boost cooperation among the three Conventions, with the ultimate aim of developing synergies in their activities on issues of mutual concern. It now also incorporates the Ramsar Convention on Wetlands.

Title: CBD's Regional Consultation workshops
Meetings summary: It is assumed that 10 regional consultation workshops (2 per region) will be held. These workshops would be open to Parties, other governments, indigenous peoples and local communities, relevant organisations and stakeholders from the relevant regions.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: This is a key activity organised by the CBD, leading to the consideration of the post-2020 global biodiversity framework.

Title: Plenary of the Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services Seventh session (IPBES 7)
Meetings summary: The Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services (IPBES) is the intergovernmental body which assesses the state of biodiversity and of the ecosystem services it provides to society, in response to requests from decision makers. The plenary of the IPBES reviews progress on its work programme. Reports will be considered for adoption and their respective summary for policymakers will be considered for approval.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: IPBES assessments are already providing the basis for informed policy-making at the international level, as well as at the national level. The regional and subregional assessments for Africa, Americas, Asia-Pacific and Europe and Central Asia together with the Thematic assessment of land degradation and restoration will be considered by the Plenary.

Title: Eighteenth meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES COP 18)
Meetings summary: Key meeting of the CITES Parties, representing the most important global meeting of the biennium on wildlife trade and sustainable use. Parties will go through an extensive agenda dealing with a large range of issues ranging from implementation of the Convention and species-specific matters to trade controls and the listing of new species in the Appendices to the CITES.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: Resolutions, decisions and intentions coming out of the meeting will likely form an important component of how national and international strategies on wildlife trade are shaped over the coming years, thus representing relevant input to the post-2020 biodiversity agenda.

Title: High-level Political Forum on Sustainable Development (HLPF) 2019
Meetings summary: The theme of HLPF 2019 will be: “Empowering people and ensuring inclusiveness and equality”. The sub-set of Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) to be reviewed in depth by HLPF 2019 will be: SDG 4 (quality education), SDG 8 (decent work and economic growth), SDG 10 (reduced inequalities), SDG13 (climate action) and SDG 16 (peace, justice and strong institutions). Goal 17 (Strengthen the means of implementation and revitalize the Global Partnership for Sustainable Development) is also considered each year.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: The HLPF is the main United Nations platform on sustainable development and it has a central role in the follow-up and review of the 2030 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) at the global level. As governments have made these commitments, relevant aspects of their agenda's and the follow-ups will be reflected in the post-2020 biodiversity strategy.

Title: IUCN Regional Conservation Forums
Meetings summary: Regional Conservation Forums (RCFs) will be held as part of the prepatory work towards the IUCN World Conservation Congress. At the RCFs IUCN Members discuss all preparations towards the Congress including matters pertaining to the work Programme of IUCN for the next quadrennium, the potential policy motions to be submitted to the Congress for approval, etc.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: It is expected that discussions during the 2019 RCFs will also help to inform IUCN’s position vis-à-vis the post-2020 biodiversity framework.

Title: OceanObs'19: An Ocean of opportunity
Meetings summary: As part of the decadal conference series, the OceanObs’19 conference will galvanize ocean observing communities to improve coordination of regional and national efforts to better observe the global ocean, to better respond to the joint scientific and societal needs of a fit-for-purpose ocean observing system, and maximize the overall benefit of more integrated observing.​ A set of Community Whitepapers will be published in a peer reviewed journal.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: Organized through the voluntary involvement of global oceanographers community, this conference is to shape strategy of global ocean observation to address scientific and socio-economic challenges, including Ecosystem health & biodiversity, in the next decade.

Title: Trondheim Conference on Biodiversity
Meetings summary: The Trondheim Conferences are a result of collaboration between the Secretariat of the UN Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD), United Nations Environment and the Norwegian government and are held every 3-4 years. The Trondheim Conferences provide a forum where participants exchange, scientific views on issues of relevance to CBD, using a neutral platform that does not need consensus on issues. The conferences create a transparent, positive and constructive atmosphere where participants exchange views freely and make recommendations based on the best possible scientific data and information.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: It has been suggested that the Trondheim Conference for Biodiversity could be used to convene the CBD's first global consultation workshop. It is assumed that the first global consultation workshop would focus on scientific issues related to the post-2020 global biodiversity framework.

Title: CBD's Global science consultation workshop
Meetings summary: It is assumed that the second global consultation workshop would focus on scientific issues related to the post 2020 global biodiversity framework and that an event such as the Trondheim Biodiversity Conference could be used to convene the consultation.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: This is a key activity organised by the CBD, leading to the consideration of the post-2020 global biodiversity framework.

Title: UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (COP25)
Meetings summary: Preventing “dangerous” human interference with the climate system is the ultimate aim of the UNFCCC.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: The UNFCCC is a “Rio Convention”, one of three adopted at the “Rio Earth Summit” in 1992. Its sister Rio Conventions are the UN Convention on Biological Diversity and the Convention to Combat Desertification. The three are intrinsically linked. It is in this context that the Joint Liaison Group was set up to boost cooperation among the three Conventions, with the ultimate aim of developing synergies in their activities on issues of mutual concern. It now also incorporates the Ramsar Convention on Wetlands. This will be an opportunity and a milestone in the lead up to 2020 where it will be important to reinforce the linkages between these agendas.

Title: 23rd Meeting of the Subsidiary Body on Scientific, Technical and Technological Advice (SBSTTA-23)
Meetings summary: Article 25 of the Convention on Biological Diversity establishes an open-ended intergovernmental scientific advisory body known as the Subsidiary Body on Scientific, Technical and Technological Advice (SBSTTA) to provide the Conference of the Parties (COP) and, as appropriate, its other subsidiary bodies, with timely advice relating to the implementation of the Convention. As a subsidiary body of the COP, SBSTTA is to report regularly to the COP on all aspects of its work. Multidisciplinary and open to participation by all Parties, SBSTTA comprises government representatives competent in the relevant field of expertise. Its functions include: providing assessments of the status of biological diversity, providing assessments of the types of measures taken in accordance with the provisions of the Convention, and responding to questions that the COP may put to the body.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: This will review the draft of GBO-5 and the IPBES global and regional assessments and prepare a recommendation on the implication of these for the post 2020 global biodiversity framework. This will be the key point of the negotiations on the content of the post-2020 agenda.

Title: 11th meeting of the Ad Hoc Open-ended Working Group on Article 8(j) and Related Provisions of the Convention on Biological Diversity (WG8J-11)
Meetings summary: This will examine the potential role of traditional knowledge, customary sustainable use and the contribution of the collective actions of indigenous peoples and local communities to the post 2020 global biodiversity framework.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: This is a key activity organised by the CBD, leading to the consideration of the post-2020 global biodiversity framework.

Title: CBD's Global policy consultation workshop
Meetings summary: It is assumed that the second global consultation workshop would focus on issues related to policy and would have approximately 100 participants representing Parties, other governments, indigenous peoples and local communities, relevant organisations and stakeholders from all regions.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: This is a key activity organised by the CBD, leading to the consideration of the post-2020 global biodiversity framework.

Title: 24th Meeting of the Subsidiary Body on Scientific, Technical and Technological Advice (SBSTTA-24)
Meetings summary: Article 25 of the Convention on Biological Diversity establishes an open-ended intergovernmental scientific advisory body known as the Subsidiary Body on Scientific, Technical and Technological Advice (SBSTTA) to provide the Conference of the Parties (COP) and, as appropriate, its other subsidiary bodies, with timely advice relating to the implementation of the Convention. As a subsidiary body of the COP, SBSTTA is to report regularly to the COP on all aspects of its work. Multidisciplinary and open to participation by all Parties, SBSTTA comprises government representatives competent in the relevant field of expertise. Its functions include: providing assessments of the status of biological diversity, providing assessments of the types of measures taken in accordance with the provisions of the Convention, and responding to questions that the COP may put to the body.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: The draft of the post-2020 global biodiversity framework will be considered, with a view to providing advice on targets to SBI-3.

Title: 3rd meeting of the Subsidiary Body on Implementation (SBI-3)
Meetings summary: The four functions and core areas of work of SBI consist of: (a) review of progress in implementation, (b) strategic actions to enhance implementation, (c) strengthening means of implementation, and (d) operations of the convention and the Protocols. The Bureau of the Conference of the Parties serves as the Bureau of the Subsidiary Body on Implementation.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: The post-2020 global biodiversity framework will be considered, with a view to developing a recommendation for COP-15.

Title: IUCN World Conservation Congress
Meetings summary: Held once every four years, the IUCN World Conservation Congress brings together several thousand leaders and decision-makers from government, civil society, indigenous peoples, business, and academia, with the goal of conserving the environment and harnessing the solutions nature offers to global challenges. The Congress aims to improve how we manage our natural environment for human, social and economic development, but this cannot be achieved by conservationists alone. The IUCN Congress is the place to put aside differences and work together to create good environmental governance, engaging all parts of society to share both the responsibilities and the benefits of conservation.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: The IUCN World Conservation Congresses produce a number of important outcomes that set the direction for the Union for the next four years. It is expected that the different outcomes from Congress will contribute to the agenda and discussions at the CBD's COP15 in the short term, and support the wider  implementation of the Convention, its objectives, and the international sustainable development agenda in the longer term.

Title: 75th Session of the UN General Assembly (UNGA 75)
Meetings summary: The 75th session of the UN General Assembly (UNGA 75) will open on Tuesday, 15 September 2020. The first day of the high-level General Debate will be Tuesday, 22 September 2020.

Title: Leaders’ summit meeting on the margins of the opening of the UN General Assembly
Meetings summary: This aims to give political direction and momentum to the development of the post-2020 global biodiversity framework.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: The aim is to provide a political push to the process in Beijing.

Title: Fifteenth meeting of the Conference of the Parties to the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD COP 15)
Meetings summary: The Conference of the Parties is the governing body of the Convention, and advances implementation of the Convention through the decisions it takes at its periodic meetings.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: The final draft of the post-2020 global biodiversity framework will be considered, with a view to adoption.

Title: The Tenth Meeting of the Parties serving as the meeting of the Parties to the Cartagena Protocol on Biosafety (COPMOP10)
Meetings summary: The Cartagena Protocol on Biosafety to the Convention on Biological Diversity is an international agreement which aims to ensure the safe handling, transport and use of living modified organisms (LMOs) resulting from modern biotechnology that may have adverse effects on biological diversity, taking also into account risks to human health. The Conference of the Parties serving as the meeting of the Parties to the Protocol (COP-MOP) currently meets every two years in conjunction with the regular meetings of the Conference of the Parties (COP) to the Convention on Biological Diversity.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: The final draft of the post-2020 global biodiversity framework will be considered, with a view to adoption.

Title: Fourth meeting of the Conference of the Parties serving as the meeting of the Parties to the Nagoya Protocol on Access and Benefit-sharing (COPMOP4)
Meetings summary: The Nagoya Protocol on Access to Genetic Resources and the Fair and Equitable Sharing of Benefits Arising from their Utilization to the Convention on Biological Diversity is an international agreement which aims at sharing the benefits arising from the utilization of genetic resources in a fair and equitable way. The Conference of the Parties serving as the meeting of the Parties to the Protocol (COP-MOP) currently meets every two years in conjunction with the regular meetings of the Conference of the Parties (COP) to the Convention on Biological Diversity.
Relevance to the CBD's post-2020 process: The final draft of the post-2020 global biodiversity framework will be considered, with a view to adoption.
